body: The bank runs that regulators feared when they announced plans for an economic bailout in September brought to mind mobs of frantic customers swarming local banks, withdrawing all their deposits. But that terminology took on a different meaning on Monday when banks across New York City were deluged by abrupt withdrawals of another kind: robberies.
title: On a Single Day, Five Banks in the City Are Robbed, in Busy Areas and in Broad Daylight

body: KUPFERSTEIN--Ceila Halper, 81, of Glen Rock, NJ, on December 17, 2008. Born in Brooklyn, she graduated from Midwood High School and attended New York University. She and her late husband Earl operated Merry Ann Girls Coat Co. for 22 years. Survived by daughters Linda Kay (Bernard Rivest); Chari Magarelli (Larry) and Tina Gelber (Scott), and two
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KUPFERSTEIN, CEILA HALPER

body: HAL RUZAL personifies the do-it-yourself spirit. He installed his own kitchen, built loft spaces for his office and sleeping area and tore down walls to convert his apartment in the meatpacking district from a one-bedroom to an open loft space. In the same vein, he is trying to sell his apartment without the aid of a real estate broker. ''The first
title: The Faces of FSBO For Sale By Owner

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; A Critic's Cityscape, and Policing the Police

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; A Critic's Cityscape, and Policing the Police: A Voice of Reason In the Concrete Jungle

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites BARTOW-PELL MANSION, 895 Shore Road North, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. Saturday at 1 p.m., ''The Original Bronx Natives,'' a lecture on the indigenous inhabitants of what is now the Bronx by Pat Ernest, the museum's director of education. Registration is recommended; bpmm.org. Tour hours: Wednesdays, Saturdays and
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN LEBOWSKI FEST There is something antithetical about Lebowski Fest, the annual celebration of ''The Big Lebowski,'' the 1998 Coen brothers movie that glorified slackerdom in the form of a long-haired stoner-bowler known as the Dude. Namely, that the event, started in 2002 by two friends in Louisville, Ky., has grown in a way that may be
title: Spare Times

body: The audience that gathered at the Bendheim Performing Arts Center here on Saturday night for a concert by Carole Demas and Paula Janis applauded politely at their rendition of the folk song ''Everybody Loves Saturday Night.'' And it clapped appreciatively for the duo's cover of Simon and Garfunkel's ''Bridge Over Troubled Water.'' But the crowd
title: For 'The Magic Garden,' It's Spring All Over Again

title: Paid Notice: Deaths KAMEN, SAMUEL E., M.D.

body: City officials said on Wednesday that they would spend $11.3 billion to create 42 schools enrolling 25,000 children over the next five years, a far less ambitious agenda for building and renovation than the capital plan presented five years ago. The scaled-down blueprint, quietly released hours after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the city's
title: With Budget Shrinking, Schools Will Get Fewer New Buildings

body: SCHIZER--Zevie B., died peacefully at age 79, after long, valiant battle with ALS. Beloved husband of Hazel for 46 years, cherished father of Dr. Deborah (Larry) Scott, Dr. Miriam Schizer (Dr. Steven) Landau, Dean David (Meredith) Schizer, adored grandfather of Rachel, Hannah, Josephine, Jacob, Eve and Judah, devoted brotherin-law of Donald and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHIZER, ZEVIE B.

body: FOR several years, thoughts of buying a home nagged at LaVerne Walker. She had lived in the same place since she was 10: a spacious two-bedroom rent-controlled apartment in Midwood, Brooklyn, that she took over from her mother. Her rent was $700 a month. She and her friends in an investment club talked incessantly about buying, but ''there was no
title: THE HUNT; Life After Rent Control

body: DI FARA, which occupies an unassuming storefront on Avenue J in Midwood, Brooklyn, has for a decade been voted the city's No. 1 pizzeria and featured in magazines, newspapers and restaurant guides around the country. Pizza Time, a decade-old pizzeria with a red neon sign and a brightly lighted interior, sits just one block west and has received
title: MIDWOOD; Pizza Coexistence

body: POLOKOFF--Kenneth A., 60 of Boca Raton, FL passed away August 31st. Born October 19, 1947 in Brooklyn, NY he graduated Midwood HS and Brooklyn College with a BA degree in Economics. He attended Baruch College from 69-74 completing 30 credits towards his MBA. Ken had over a 40 year career on Wall Street as a Corporate Bonds Trader and Sr. Vice
title: Paid Notice: Deaths POLOKOFF, KENNETH A.

body: BERNSTEIN--Gladys. It is with great sadness we report the death of Gladys Bernstein nee Rolnick, March 15, 1918 September 28, 2008. Gladys was the wife of the late Arthur Bernstein. She is survived by her sister Surita Baum and her children Elizabeth Harrington and Michael Bernstein and their spouses Martin Harrington and Lori Bernstein. Gladys had
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BERNSTEIN, GLADYS

author: E-mail: joeberg@nytimes.com
body: THERE have been few odder matchups in Westchester than the dude ranch here that for two decades has been the home of an Orthodox yeshiva. Teenage boys and young men spending dawn to midnight plumbing the labyrinthine arguments of the Talmud have spent nights sleeping in Western-style low-slung buildings called Dodge City and Dallas. It seems like a
title: COUNTY LINES | CORTLANDT; Trouble in Dodge City For a Dude-Ranch Yeshiva

body: $11.25 MILLION 2026 Ocean Avenue Midwood, Brooklyn A Brooklyn real estate firm has bought this seven-story building with 58 apartments, a parking garage and seven doctor's offices. Buyer: Herald Realty L.L.C. Seller: IJD Realty Broker: Aaron Jungreis, Rosewood Realty Group
title: Recent Sale

author: Ben Gibberd is the author of ''New York Waters: Profiles From the Edge,'' with the photographer Randy Duchaine.
body: ARTHUR NERSESIAN, a 49-year-old playwright, poet and novelist whose wavy gray hair gives him the look of a 1960s English professor, rummaged through the black messenger bag lying next to him in a booth at the Moonstruck Diner in the East Village. Then he gleefully pulled out what appeared to be three coverless, battered paperbacks and slid them
title: Writing the Myth of Moses

body: Address: 827 East 21st Street (between Farragut and Glenwood Roads) The Property: Near Brooklyn College and a 20-minute subway ride to either the beach or Manhattan, this three-story house was built in 1910 and has an addition with a separate entrance that can be used as a professional office space. The original house has a center staircase, six
title: BUY OF THE WEEK/SOUTH MIDWOOD, BROOKLYN

body: NEXT weekend, according to nonpolice estimates, 10 quadrillion people will sweat their way down Eastern Parkway, dancing and eating and waving the flags of more than a dozen Caribbean nations during the city's most famous street party, the West Indian American Day Carnival. Into the food but not so much the ear-splitting music? Explore the West
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | CARIBBEAN FOOD; In Brooklyn, Every Palate Is an Island

body: International RAPID RESPONSE TO A RAID In a Fragile Iraq Province Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq ordered an investigation into a raid Tuesday that recalled the attacks once carried out regularly by the Shiite-dominated security forces. His rapid response reflected fears that the raid, in which a Sunni provincial governor was arrested
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: August 20, 2008

body: HERE'S a conversation you might hear (or have) on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn: ''Hey, let's get some schnitzel.'' ''Schnitzi or Schnitzel King?'' ''Schnitzi. Those guys know how to sauce a schnitzel.'' No matter what you think of schnitzel, it's fun to say. And you'll be saying more of it: Schnitzel is on the rise in New York. Schnitzi plans to
title: $25 AND UNDER; Chicken In Global Attire

body: FROM a distance, the wide aisles crammed with organic pear juice, whole-grain cereal and trans-fat-free chips, the wood floors and red pendant lighting make Pomegranate look like any other upscale supermarket. But look closer. Next to the Jif peanut butter, there's white chocolate spread with a label in Hebrew. Abutting the panko are whole-wheat
title: Sushi and Kishke Under One Roof

body: Streaked gold and green, candy-stripe figs from California look too beautiful to eat. But slice one of these exquisite fruits in half and you'll see why Dan Spitz, the founder of the Orchard, a produce market in Brooklyn, calls them raspberry figs. The inside is the color of raspberry jam and even has a similar sweet-tart flavor and texture, thanks
title: FOOD STUFF; A Fig Reveals Its Inner Raspberry

body: Every summer, curious creatures infiltrate New York City's biggest parks. They number in the dozens, walk on their hind legs, are khaki in color and exceedingly amiable by nature. Their most distinguished markings are their wide-brimmed Smokey Bear hats. They are Urban Park Ranger fellows, possessors of what may be the best, if not most unusual,
title: A Summer Job That Promises Nature Walks for Pay

body: He may look cool and relaxed in his white Mercedes, golden tan and trademark pink polo shirts, but for Peter Stein, summer is no vacation. Mr. Stein, 63, is the enigmatic union chief who has been a towering figure in New York City's lifeguard system since the 1960s, when he helped unionize city lifeguards and later became president of Local 508,
title: Union Boss Criticized After a Death in the Surf

body: When he was 5 years old, Billy O'Connor stood on a Brooklyn street with his mother and two sisters, and for the last time, watched his father fight a fire. It was August 2, 1978. The O'Connors were supposed to go the beach that day, but when they went to the firehouse that morning to pick up Billy's father, Firefighter William O'Connor, at the end
title: A Memory They Refuse To Let Fade

body: Cable television subscribers in New York City will have another company to choose from starting on Monday when Verizon begins selling programming, taking on companies like Cablevision and Time Warner Cable. Verizon Communications, the city's largest phone company, will start hooking up cable customers for television in parts of 108 neighborhoods
title: Verizon Begins Competing For Cable TV Customers

body: For an overwhelming majority of Democrats in the State Senate, this is a relatively low-stress primary season. Most are facing token opposition, at best, and few are seriously worried about their re-election prospects. A notable exception is State Senator Kevin S. Parker, 41, a three-term incumbent who represents a district that covers the Brooklyn
title: 3 Democrats Vie for a Senate Seat in Brooklyn

body: Call it congestion parking. In what amounts to congestion pricing for parking spaces, parking meter rates would double during heavy traffic periods in portions of Manhattan and Brooklyn as part of an experimental city program beginning this fall, officials said Wednesday. The program's goal is to increase turnover in curbside parking spaces in the
title: City to Test Peak Rates for Parking Meters

body: Late one night, shortly after Kai Lui and his wife, Laura Campbell-Lui, moved into their Queen Anne-style house in Midwood, Brooklyn, she shook him awake, insisting that she heard intruders. Mr. Lui went to investigate and discovered noises coming from the fourth-floor attic. He called the police. ''They had their weapons drawn,'' said Mr. Lui, a
title: The City's Latest Real Estate Fight: Humans Against Raccoons

body: A mustang named Benny suffered a stone bruise. Dave, a Peruvian Paso, slipped and gouged his ankle. A thoroughbred named Sham, a former show horse, now needs regular hock injections for his stiffening joints. Fran Levy, their owner, said that Benny, Dave and Sham, along with countless other horses, have suffered injuries while trotting on the
title: For Riders and Mounts, Rough Going in Prospect Park

body: An article in some editions on May 22 about the questioning of three Brooklyn high school students after notes describing a murder plot were discovered included erroneous information from the police about the McDonald's restaurant where one of the named targets worked. It is in Brooklyn but not ''across the street'' from the school, James Madison
title: CORRECTIONS

body: FOR Maggie Tobin and Bob Mason, the last straw in Park Slope was the parking. The couple, who have two young children, lived there for eight years and loved being near Prospect Park and surrounded by friends. But when the time came to buy, they wanted more space and found the prices too high, and they decided they could also live without the ritual
title: LIVING IN KENSINGTON, BROOKLYN; Name From London, People From Everywhere

body: WEST MIDWOOD HOUSE $1,275,000 BROOKLYN: 1304 Glenwood Road (at Argyle Road) A three-story 1910 Victorian with five bedrooms, two full and two half baths, a wraparound porch, front and back yards, a deck, a two-car garage and a private driveway. Caterina Peters (718) 780-8145, Prudential Douglas Elliman; www.elliman.com. Open house Sunday, 1 to 3
title: On the Market

body: Three students at James Madison High School in Brooklyn were questioned by investigators on Wednesday after notes were discovered describing a plan to kill people in and around the school, the police said. Classes were not affected. The notes were discovered near the end of the school day. The confiscated notes outlined a plan to kill three people
title: Students Questioned About Plot To Kill Three

body: Mike Welsh walked into Larry's Barber Shop one afternoon and witnessed two men getting clipped, one in a barber's chair, the other on a small television screen. ''What are we watching today?'' Mr. Welsh asked Larry Babizhaev, the shop's owner. ''The Godfather: Part II,'' Mr. Babizhaev replied, his scissors dancing atop a customer's head. ''Why, you
title: Gangster Love: Mob Movies Are a Hit at a Manhattan Barber Shop

body: Faced with a deluge of children vying for coveted slots in gifted and talented programs, and a dearth of top-scoring applicants, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced plans on Wednesday to broaden the city's new policy for admitting children to the programs. The change, which is expected to be approved at a meeting on Thursday by the Panel for
title: Broader Rule Sought to Pick Gifted Pupils

body: SCHNEIWEISS--Hynda Lessman , survived by husband Saul, brother Morton, many nieces, nephews and cousins. Born 1925, Chicago. Lived in Midwood, Brooklyn, last 66 years. Active in community. On community Board 14, 70th Precinct Council. 22 years fifth grade volunteer school, teaching, learning leader. Funeral service April 1 at Kirschenbaum's, Ave. H
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHNEIWEISS, HYNDA LESSMAN

body: IT was the cats that caused Tania Dudina and George Kokoris to think about buying a place. Last spring, the couple, living in a studio in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, adopted two cats. One had ringworm, a skin fungus. The cats, Loki and Pliooshka, needed months of treatment with medications, ointments and shampoos. They had to be kept apart, too, lest
title: THE HUNT; More Than a Pet Project

body: LEFFERTS MANOR TOWN HOUSE $1,375,000 BROOKLYN: 218 Midwood Street (at Rogers Avenue) A 1909 limestone corner house with five bedrooms and one and a half baths on two floors, and a ground floor professional office with one bath, a side entrance and a three-car garage. Bette Cunningham, Brown Harris Stevens (718) 399-4120; www.bhsbrooklyn.com TAXES:
title: Lefferts Manor Town House

body: THERE was great excitement last fall in the part of Brooklyn known affectionately as Victorian Flatbush when the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission recommended that Midwood Park and Fiske Terrace, two neighborhoods within this network of communities south of Prospect Park, be designated a historic district. On Tuesday, five months after the
title: VICTORIAN FLATBUSH; Peaked Roofs, Crossed Fingers

body: GERRY GRUNSFELD, a genial 32-year-old lawyer who grew up in England and now lives in a narrow two-story house in Midwood, Brooklyn, has the kind of backyard you're not sure whether to envy or pity. True, it's green space, a rare and precious commodity for a city dweller. But it's not much bigger than a putting green and it's hemmed in by buildings
title: Backyards, Beware: An Orchard Wants Your Spot

body: Dalilah Muhammad led Cardozo High School of Queens to the girls' team title with 78 points in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor championships at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Muhammad won the high jump, finished second in the 55-meter hurdles and was third leg on Cardozo's 4x800 winning relay (9:27.11). Midwood
title: SPORTS BRIEFING | TRACK AND FIELD; Cardozo Wins Girls Team Title

body: AS a young man, the composer John Corigliano swore that there were two things he would never do: write a symphony and teach composition. He has since learned the folly of speaking in absolutes. By now Mr. Corigliano has written three symphonies, the first two having won prestigious awards. And thanks to a recent Lehman College subway ad campaign,
title: MUSIC; Life Past the Classroom And After the Orchestra

body: Working as an undercover narcotics officer is among the most dangerous jobs on the police force. You have to pretend to be an addict and win the trust of dealers. But if you must do the job, it would seem, a good place to land would be the area designated by the Police Department as Brooklyn South. For as large as it is, covering the vast territory
title: Undercover Work Seen as Mix of Art, Temptation and, Sometimes, Corruption

body: Manhattan FINANCIAL DISTRICT $765,000 15 Broad Street (Exchange Place) (Downtown by Philippe Starck) 689-sq.-ft. studio condo in a renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doormen, concierge; bath with soaking tub, 11-ft. ceilings, oversize windows, south and east exposures; common courtyard and roof deck in building; common charge $450; taxes $3,600
title: Residential Sales

From theme lines like GE's ''We bring good things to life,'' to Pepsi's ''The
title: Paid Notice: Deaths DUSENBERRY, PHIL
